messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:47): do the accessibility folks really believe that RDF will give AT more understanding?
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (23:49): I would guess that they are not all of one point of view
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, that's what I'm wondering

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: people mistakenly think that the ability to write declarations for a custom vocabulary and put it in a namespace gives understanding without prior agreement
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:52): (well, mistakenly IMO anyway)
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (23:52): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: by without prior agreement you mean
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (23:53): oops hit the return button by accident

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:53): I mean that if you declare your own custom vocabulary in some formal way, that in no way aids anyone in understanding that vocabulary if they are not specifically aware of it
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (23:54): Okay, yes that's what I thought
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:54): it's like defining your own FooML and then expecting UAs to instantly understand it
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:55): got told a few days ago that browsers already support XHTML2 :P
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:55): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, of course the do!  There's a working example on the web ;-)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:55): anyway, Tina joined the XHTML2 WG, so that's one positive step from the flamage
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:56): yeah, she joined last week
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, http://w3future.com/html/examples.xml?notransform
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:57): (they don't like telling anyone this, but that relies on proprietary extensions in major browsers to actually be functional)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:57): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: what extensions?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:57): view the CSS
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:57): does it work in Safari?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:58): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: does for me
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:59): is that page itself allegedly XHTML2?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:59): ah, it's been changed since I last looked at it
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:59): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: where? I see nothing proprietary skimming through it
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:59): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: with XSL, though
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:59): they now use XSLT to transform it to HTML
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (23:59): it's XSLT transformed
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:00): it used to contain properties like '-o-link' (I think that's it) for making the links work, and binding XBL1 for Mozilla
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:01): I wonder if their transform would actually handle xml-events and xforms (they declare the namespaces but don't use them)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:02): guesses no, since scripting would have to work on the post-transform DOM)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:02): yeah, that's weird
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:02): XMLEvents is just another poorly designed technology though
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:02): XBL makes it obsolete
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:03): Does that that mean I don't have to learn it? goodie
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:03): xml-events makes easy things hard and hard things hard
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:06): ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc, you never have to learn anything that comes out of the XHTML2 and related groups
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:06): did the XHTML2WG make xml events?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:06): g'nite
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:07): The less the better
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:09): wow, I love how they replace <img ... onclick=",,,"> with something even easier: ...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:09): <img src="button.gif" alt="OK">
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:09): <script ev:event="activate" type="application/x-javascript">
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:09): doactivate(event);

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:13): ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc: X-Path in browsers (well Firefox at least) http://www-xray.ast.cam.ac.uk/ b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea/mozilla/xpath-tutorial.html
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:13): was sure that got moved to the Mozilla wiki somewhere
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:20): thanks

ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:22): I'll give it a read. I got some stuff working in FF and Opera, and got some other stuff working in IE. It all seemed completely different, but then I didn't have the faintest idea what I was doing.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:23): I have no idea what IE does. If it doesn't follow the spec, that document won't help
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:26): as I recall the expressions resolved similarly, but it was figuring out how to invoke them that was quirky
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:45): a problem I've had in trying to understand the discussions is this: where to draw a boundary on what is HTML -- where are its boundaries?
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:46): we've got script with document.write, we've got some DOM, CSS is sorta there in a presentational sense, sorta in a semantic sense
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:47): we've got events, we've got XML and object, and all the foreign content
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:49): for reading and writing files we've got webforms (and various x-things) and I can't remember what the RFC was that covered file output
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:50): when I find issues concerning say a weird document.write script that seems to change styles in one browser but not in another I have no way

ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (00:51): to figure out even which spec to begin looking in to know if it's a bug or my misunderstanding of how it's supposed to be -- the specs have gotten a bit spread out
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): so are all these e-mails still actually introducing new information, or is each e-mail repeating an earlier e-mail?
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:05): The similarity coefficient would appear to be high
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:22): Is it just me, or does a subject like "Re: Getting beyond the ping pong match (was RE: Cleaning House)" make absolutely no sense?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:23): It makes sense in context, but the discussion itself is bordering on senseless :)
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (01:24): I don't think it makes sense in context, either
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (01:24): the ping pong match was so much fun that now we need to clean the house
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (01:26): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: some of them are just multi-page ways of saying "+1" to an earlier email
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:27): good times
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (01:31): I'm really not enjoying the way DanC has interpreted the decision process

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (01:32): we have votes overwhelmingly in favor of three resolutions but there is no way to tell if they carry until magical pronouncement from the chairs, which might not happen until after an unspecified period of negotiating with the few dissenters

ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:44): I rather like that -- it gives a sort of independent opportunity to see if consensus were indeed possible -- or whether substantive arguments had in fact been overlooked
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:45): Now certainly how consensus can work (or whether or not it is possible) in a group of this size
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:45): that is a reasonable question.
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:47): I did rather hope that the "ping pong match" and the "clean the house" threads would have helped the discussion emerge to some higher level
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:48): like maybe it's time to bring in Jimmy Carter

ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:49): There was a proposal before the US Congress in the late 1970's early 1980's to fund a "peace academy" -- the premise was that skills of making peace should be funded every bit as much as the military academies.
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:50): I think in marketing they call it "buy in"
ca4923f2d198f6bbff488e483461b3bc (01:58): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: it looks like you and I agreed on the copyright issue on that one objection.
